Award.AwardTitle: Infrared Mapping of Magnetic Fields in Star-Forming Regions in the Milky Way
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many galaxies in the Universe have large spiral-shaped structures in flat disks. Those structures consist of gas and stars, many of whose properties are governed by processes involving magnetic fields. This project is a study of such structures in our own Milky Way galaxy using observations at near-infrared wavelengths. Catalogs containing thousands of times more detections than available previously will be produced for general astronomical use and released to the entire scientific community. Three graduate students will be trained in using various aspects of these data to study topics ranging from star formation in the Milky Way to comparing it to the properties of other nearby galaxies like our own.

The Galactic magnetic B-field has barely been characterized and its influence on the interstellar medium (ISM) is poorly known. Comprehensive analysis of the recently completed Galactic Plane Infrared Polarization Survey (GPIPS) data set will provide an important leap forward. This will include quantitative tests of models of the Galactic B-field in the disk as well as identifying the locations and natures of the regions in the disk now seen to exhibit strong departures from the general disk-parallel B-field alignment. Connecting what is seen in the GPIPS data for the Milky Way disk to large-scale B-fields in nearby edge-on galaxies will provide vital context as well as test whether the B-fields traced by synchrotron radio polarization, arising from hot plasma, connect smoothly to the B-fields in the cool, star-forming ISM. Deeper observations of important Galactic regions will answer B-field related questions with milli-parsec resolution in quiescent and star-forming sites and provide key tests of the two B-field model paradigms (strong vs weak fields). Studies resulting from using the Mimir instrument and from GPIPS provide vital B-field context, from the diffuse outer ISM layers of molecular clouds into the dense, core regions. New, K-band Mimir polarimetry of infrared dark clouds and well-known massive cloud core star formation regions will reach deep enough to provide context for the high column density zones observed with millimeter and submillimeter interferometric polarimetry.

GPIPS and Mimir data products have impact outside the study of B-fields in the ISM. Community use of GPIPS data will yield new findings on stars, stellar evolution, star clusters, and Galactic structure and assembly. Project support of GPIPS data products and software ensure their utility and legacy. The program of bringing undergraduate and graduate students to Arizona to operate Mimir on the Perkins telescope for class-based projects will continue and will include high school students participating in BU's RISE summer program. Though modest in numbers (~100 students in 8 years), these trips to the telescope have had profound personal and career impact on the students participating, be they from graduate or undergraduate observational classes or from the introductory, non-majors astronomy courses at BU. Public presentation opportunities at the Boston Museum of Science, BU Astronomy Department?s weekly open nights, and elsewhere will be actively pursued for this project. Finally, three graduate students will complete PhDs and several undergraduates and High School students will gain valuable research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to characterize magnetic fields in the interstellar medium from the large scales that span whole galaxies down to the smallest scales associated with the near environments of young star-forming regions. The collection of individual studies making up this project chiefly utilized new near-infrared polarimetric data obtained by our Mimir instrument on the 1.8m Perkins telescope operated by Lowell Observatory outside Flagstaff, Arizona. Three graduate students pursued PhD dissertation research projects under this grant and two (Jordan Montgomery and Sadia Hoq) successfully defended their dissertations and were awarded PhDs.

Hoq's dissertation work had two thrusts. The first sought to isolate and study the member stars comprising open star clusters in the outer Galaxy, to probe the Perseus spiral arm's magnetic field properties. She found that the magnetic field in Perseus does indeed appear to be stronger than in the interarm regions between spiral arms. Her second investigation area probed the nature of magnetic fields in and around infrared dark clouds - dense gas and dust clouds that contain the raw materials from which intermediate and high-mass stars are forming. She studied one cloud in close detail and a sample of about 30 clouds with a broader touch. Again, the magnetic field was found to strengthen within the one cloud and there was some evidence of alignment of the long axes of the members of the 30 cloud sample with the magnetic field surrounding each cloud.

Mongomery's dissertation sought to address whether the polarization patterns we measured for edge-on galaxies are due to magnetic fields in those galaxies or to scattering of starlight off the dust there. To find the answer, he studied local reflection nebulae in detail with optical and near-infrared imaging polarimetry, newly obtained at the Perkins telescope. He found an interesting dichotomy of polarization behaviour, such that dust in regions with high ultra-violet starlight illumination exhibited one polarization pattern with wavelength while dust far from such illumination exhibited another characteristic pattern. He next looked to the center of the M82 starburst galaxy for clues as to whether dust in external galaxies behaved similarly to dust in the local reflection nebulae. He was able to isolate which regions of M82 showed strong reflection and which did not, using a new Bayesian (machine learning) approach. Finally, he applied his findings to a sample of edge-on galaxies, for which he had obtained near-infrared imaging polarimetry with Mimir on the Perkins. He concluded that although scattering dominates the polarization patterns of galaxies when viewed at optical wavelengths, in the infrared the polarization does faithfully reveal magnetic field properties. Using this finding, he ascertained the numbers of spiral arms in these edge-on galaxies and which side of each galaxy was the leading or trailing rotation side.

We also completed the final data collection for our 10-year long survey of the polarization of starlight within a large swath of the disk our Milky Way galaxy, and have begun detailed analyses of this fabulous data set.

Detailed studies of individual dusty dark clouds were also conducted to ascertain the role of magnetic fields in filamentary molecular clouds and ones for which stars have not yet formed (prestellar clouds).

Finally, as a result of our access to Mimir and the Perkins for long observing runs, we followed the infrared brightness of the enigmatic Tabby's Star during 45 nights in the early summer of 2017, when it again entered into a season of brightness dips. While we continue to analyze the brightness data, we found that our positional information was sufficient to rule out the purported companion as being a cause of the activity in this stellar system. This project was the focus of the summer internships of two high school students, who joined our team under a program run by Boston University, and earned co-authorships on the published paper.
